t: Job 5
“Call*pn now; is there anyone who will answer you? To*ld which of the holy ones will you turn?
Surely*ln vexation kills the fool, and*ld jealousy slays the simple.
I*ln have seen the fool taking root, but*ld suddenly I cursed his dwelling.
His*ln children are far from safety; they*ld are crushed in the gate, and*ld there is no one to deliver them.
The*ln hungry eat his harvest, and*ld he takes it even out of thorns, and*ld the thirsty pant after his wealth.
For*ln affliction does not come from the dust, nor*ld does trouble sprout from the ground,
but*ln man is born to trouble as*ld the sparks fly upward.
“As*pn for me, I would seek God, and*ld to God would I commit my cause,
who*ln does great things and unsearchable, marvelous*ld things without number:
he*ln gives rain on the earth and*ld sends waters on the fields;
he*ln sets on high those who are lowly, and*ld those who mourn are lifted to safety.
He*ln frustrates the devices of the crafty, so*ld that their hands achieve no success.
He*ln catches the wise in their own craftiness, and*ld the schemes of the wily are brought to a quick end.
They*ln meet with darkness in the daytime and*ld grope at noonday as in the night.
But*ln he saves the needy from the sword of their mouth and*ld from the hand of the mighty.
So*ln the poor have hope, and*ld injustice shuts her mouth.
“Behold,*pn blessed is the one whom God reproves; therefore*ld despise not the discipline of the Almighty.
For*ln he wounds, but he binds up; he*ld shatters, but his hands heal.
He*ln will deliver you from six troubles; in*ld seven no evil shall touch you.
In*ln famine he will redeem you from death, and*ld in war from the power of the sword.
You*ln shall be hidden from the lash of the tongue, and*ld shall not fear destruction when it comes.
At*ln destruction and famine you shall laugh, and*ld shall not fear the beasts of the earth.
For*ln you shall be in league with the stones of the field, and*ld the beasts of the field shall be at peace with you.
You*ln shall know that your tent is at peace, and*ld you shall inspect your fold and miss nothing.
You*ln shall know also that your offspring shall be many, and*ld your descendants as the grass of the earth.
You*ln shall come to your grave in ripe old age, like*ld a sheaf gathered up in its season.
Behold,*ln this we have searched out; it is true. Hear,*ld and know it for your good.”
